content: row go bottom to top you are basically doing the pattern pixel by pixel same idea applies to crochet colourwork too remember colour dominance especially for the patterns like the windowpane pattern if you want to play around and try to create your own colourwork pattern stitch fiddle is a great website to use or you can use excel with the column cell widths brought right down to create pixels checkered 6 5 4 3 2 1 6 5 4 3 2 1 r1-3 knit 3 in colour a knit 3 in colour b r3-6 knit 3 in colour b knit 3 in colour a you can easily adapt this to a repeat of 4 with 4 stitches and rounds of each colour for a larger checker windowpane 4 3 2 1 4 3 2 1 r1 knit in colour a r2-4 knit 3 in colour b knit 1 in colour a for a windowpane i would cast on in colour a and start and end with a r1 5 dianna truong version 1b july 2025 gingham 4 3 2 1 4 3 2 1 r1-2 knit 2 in colour a knit 2 in colour b r3-4 knit 2 in colour b knit 2 in colour c my previous scrunchies i used white for ginghams but have found that i prefer the darkest colour as the border with a nice crocheted edge so now i d cast on in colour a and knit 1 row in colour a before starting the pattern candy stripe 5 4 3 2 1 5 4 3 2 1 r1 knit 3 in colour a knit 2 in colour b r2 knit 1 in colour b knit 3 in colour a knit 1 in colour b r3 knit 2 in colour b knit 2 in colour a r4 knit 1 in colour a knit 2 in colour b knit 2 in colour b this one can easily be adjusted to have a 1 1 ratio of colours i would do 3 stitches in r5 knit 2 in colour a knit 2 in colour b knit both colours for even stripes a 3 2 ratio 1 in colour a would get you a stronger contrast depending which yarn is held on the left for dominance the blue scrunchie pictured is a 3 2 ratio with dark blue as dominant 6 dianna truong version 1b july 2025 houndstooth 4 3 2 1 4 3 2 1 also called dogtooth by some this one works best with high contrast colours like black and white i m planning on trying a medium contrast one soon which i hope will still
